<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Four coordination polymers with binuclear subunit, helical chain, distorted triangular and (4, 4) topological layer were generated by varying the substituent of isophthalate in the ternary Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazolate-isophthalate system. Three of them exhibit metamagnetic transition and typically antiferromagnetic interactions.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Four coordination polymers with binuclear subunit, helical chain, distorted triangular and (4, 4) topological layer were generated by varying the substituent of isophthalate in the ternary CoII-3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazolate-isophthalate system. Three of them exhibit metamagnetic transition and typically antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Four 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz)-based cobalt(II/III) coordination polymers, {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hdatrz)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Co(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)(Hdatrz)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Co(datrz)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-aminoisophthalate, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-methylisophthalate and NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-nitroisophthalate), were hydro-/solvothermally synthesized by changing the substituents attached on the isophthalate coligand, which were structurally and magnetically characterized. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a corrugated layer with dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunits extended by three-connected NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> connectors. Constructed from the same mixed ligands, both <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit robust three-dimensional (3D) frameworks consisting of helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chain and corner-sharing triangular {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1,N2,N4-datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> layer, respectively. By contrast, two bis-monodentate NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and two μ-N1,N4-datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions connect tetrahedral Co(III) sites into a (4, 4) grid-like layer of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Thus, the substituent of the isophthalate coligand is observed to virtually influence the overall structures of the resulting complexes by changing the binding modes of the coligand and coordination polyhedra. Additionally, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a metamagnetic transition from antiferromagnetic ordering to weak ferromagnetic state. Instead, typically antiferromagnetic interactions are respectively mediated by the cyclic triazolate ligand along the helical chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and in the distorted triangular layer of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Four 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz)-based cobalt(II/III) coordination polymers, {[Co2(Hdatrz)(NH2-ip)2]·0.5H2O}
n
 (1), [Co(CH3OH)(Hdatrz)(CH3-ip)]
n
 (2), {[Co2(datrz)2(CH3-ip)]·2.5H2O}
n
 (3) and {[Co(datrz)(NO2-ip)]·H2O}
n
 (4) (NH2-ip2−
=5-aminoisophthalate, CH3-ip2−
=5-methylisophthalate and NO2-ip2−
=5-nitroisophthalate), were hydro-/solvothermally synthesized by changing the substituents attached on the isophthalate coligand, which were structurally and magnetically characterized. Complex 1 is a corrugated layer with dimeric {Co2(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}4+ subunits extended by three-connected NH2-ip2− connectors. Constructed from the same mixed ligands, both 2 and 3 exhibit robust three-dimensional (3D) frameworks consisting of helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chain and corner-sharing triangular {Co2(μ3-N1,N2,N4-datrz)2}2+ layer, respectively. By contrast, two bis-monodentate NO2-ip2− and two μ-N1,N4-datrz− anions connect tetrahedral Co(III) sites into a (4, 4) grid-like layer of 4. Thus, the substituent of the isophthalate coligand is observed to virtually influence the overall structures of the resulting complexes by changing the binding modes of the coligand and coordination polyhedra. Additionally, complex 1 exhibits a metamagnetic transition from antiferromagnetic ordering to weak ferromagnetic state. Instead, typically antiferromagnetic interactions are respectively mediated by the cyclic triazolate ligand along the helical chain of 2 and in the distorted triangular layer of 3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Structural design and functional modification of paramagnetic coordination polymers (CPs) have always received enormous interest in crystal engineering, magnetic materials science and theoretical understandings on the magnetostructural relationships . Among diverse paramagnetic transition metal ions with different numbers of unpaired d electron, cobalt ion has becoming one of good candidates as a spin carrier resulting from its strong single-ion anisotropy and unquenched spin–orbit coupling . Up to date, lots of interesting Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-containing CPs, such as isolated helical/bent chains, coplanar/wave-like layers and extended microporous/pillared-layer frameworks, have been consequently obtained by varying the organic magnetic mediators, which have exhibited intriguingly long-range magnetic ordering and/or single-chain magnetic behaviors . On the other hand, heterobridge-involved magnetic systems constructed from heterocyclic triazolate and bent carboxylate mediators have recently drawn great attention due to their collaborative effect on structural and magnetic adjustments of the resulting CPs . Crystallographically, both the cyclic triazolate and the deprotonated carboxylate group can adopt various binding modes to aggregate discrete spin carriers into dense subunits with variable core numbers and core topologies, accompanying the transfer of the typically anti- and/or ferromagnetic interactions with variable coupling constants. Especially, the type of superexchange interaction for bidentate bridging carboxylate is found to be conformation-dependent. Moreover, the rigid phenyl-based polycarboxylates can behave as polytopic connectors to essentially extend the versatile subunits into intriguing polymeric frameworks, in which the intralayer/interchain distance separated by the phenyl moiety is suitable to induce interesting metamagnetic transition . More interestingly, the chemical modifications for the triazolate ligands can change their crystallographically symmetry and influence their binding behaviors towards the spin carriers, which can potentially lead to the asymmetric superexchange pathways for interesting canted antiferromagnetism. Apparently, the mixed carboxylate–triazolate mediators can play important and complicated roles for the resulting structures and magnetic properties of the resulting samples. To continuing the magnetostructural investigations of the triazolate–carboxylate-Co(II) ion-involved systems , self-assembly reactions of 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz) and inorganic Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> sources were performed in the presence of different 5-substituted isophthalic acids (R-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip) (R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>–NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, –CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and –NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). The particular purpose of the present contribution is to investigate the steric and/or electronic effect of the substituent appended around the isophthalate on the structure and magnetic properties. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal structures and magnetic properties of the resulting four CPs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Structural design and functional modification of paramagnetic coordination polymers (CPs) have always received enormous interest in crystal engineering, magnetic materials science and theoretical understandings on the magnetostructural relationships . Among diverse paramagnetic transition metal ions with different numbers of unpaired d electron, cobalt ion has becoming one of good candidates as a spin carrier resulting from its strong single-ion anisotropy and unquenched spin–orbit coupling . Up to date, lots of interesting CoII-containing CPs, such as isolated helical/bent chains, coplanar/wave-like layers and extended microporous/pillared-layer frameworks, have been consequently obtained by varying the organic magnetic mediators, which have exhibited intriguingly long-range magnetic ordering and/or single-chain magnetic behaviors . On the other hand, heterobridge-involved magnetic systems constructed from heterocyclic triazolate and bent carboxylate mediators have recently drawn great attention due to their collaborative effect on structural and magnetic adjustments of the resulting CPs . Crystallographically, both the cyclic triazolate and the deprotonated carboxylate group can adopt various binding modes to aggregate discrete spin carriers into dense subunits with variable core numbers and core topologies, accompanying the transfer of the typically anti- and/or ferromagnetic interactions with variable coupling constants. Especially, the type of superexchange interaction for bidentate bridging carboxylate is found to be conformation-dependent. Moreover, the rigid phenyl-based polycarboxylates can behave as polytopic connectors to essentially extend the versatile subunits into intriguing polymeric frameworks, in which the intralayer/interchain distance separated by the phenyl moiety is suitable to induce interesting metamagnetic transition . More interestingly, the chemical modifications for the triazolate ligands can change their crystallographically symmetry and influence their binding behaviors towards the spin carriers, which can potentially lead to the asymmetric superexchange pathways for interesting canted antiferromagnetism. Apparently, the mixed carboxylate–triazolate mediators can play important and complicated roles for the resulting structures and magnetic properties of the resulting samples. To continuing the magnetostructural investigations of the triazolate–carboxylate-Co(II) ion-involved systems , self-assembly reactions of 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz) and inorganic CoII sources were performed in the presence of different 5-substituted isophthalic acids (R-H2ip) (R=–NH2, –CH3 and –NO2). The particular purpose of the present contribution is to investigate the steric and/or electronic effect of the substituent appended around the isophthalate on the structure and magnetic properties. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal structures and magnetic properties of the resulting four CPs.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">Materials and Instruments</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">All initial chemicals were commercially purchased (Hdatrz was from Acros and other analytical-grade reagents were from Tianjin Chemical Reagent Factory) and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Labs) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere at a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA for Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with a scan speed of 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>. The simulated PXRD patterns were calculated using single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and processed by the free Mercury v1.4 program provided by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Magnetic susceptibilities were acquired on a Quantum Design (SQUID) magnetometer MPMS-XL-7 with crystalline samples, in which the phase purity of the samples were determined by PXRD experiments. The data were corrected for TIP and the diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants. The diamagnetism from the sample container were also corrected.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and Instruments
All initial chemicals were commercially purchased (Hdatrz was from Acros and other analytical-grade reagents were from Tianjin Chemical Reagent Factory) and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Labs) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000–400cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800°C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5°C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60kV and 300mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ
=1.5406Å), with a scan speed of 2deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The simulated PXRD patterns were calculated using single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and processed by the free Mercury v1.4 program provided by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Magnetic susceptibilities were acquired on a Quantum Design (SQUID) magnetometer MPMS-XL-7 with crystalline samples, in which the phase purity of the samples were determined by PXRD experiments. The data were corrected for TIP and the diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants. The diamagnetism from the sample container were also corrected.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Co2(Hdatrz)(NH2-ip)2]·0.5H2O}n (1)
A mixture containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2mg, 0.2mmol), Hdatrz (19.8mg, 0.2mmol) and NH2-H2ip (36.2mg, 0.2mmol) was dissolved in mixed H2O–CH3OH (v:v=1:1, 10.0mL) solution, and the initial pH value of the reactant mixture was adjusted to 6 by triethylamine. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0mL) and heated at 165°C for 96h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2.9°Ch−1, red block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water and dried in air (Yield: 50%, based on NH2-H2ip). Anal. Calc. for C36H32Co4N14O17: C, 37.01; H, 2.76; N, 16.78. Found: C, 37.04; H, 2.65; N, 16.72%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3409 (br), 3319 (w), 3167 (w), 1625 (s), 1588 (s), 1559 (s), 1481 (s), 1449 (s), 1386 (s), 1322 (w), 1011 (m), 985 (m), 952 (w), 797 (w), 778 (w), 724 (w), 666 (w).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st055">X-ray data collection and structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Diffraction intensities for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker APEX–II QUAZAR diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å by using the <ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> scan technique at 173 (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), 296 (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), respectively. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semiempirical multi-scan absorption corrections were applied by <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>
, and the program <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps> was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-97 and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97 programs . Non-H atoms were located by difference Fourier maps and subjected to anisotropic refinement. Organic hydrogen atom was added according to theoretical models. Two and a half free water molecules in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were disordered, and the diffused electron densities resulting from these residual solvent molecules were removed from the data using the SQUEEZE routing of <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> and refined further using the data generated . One exocyclic amino group (N10) of datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is positionally disordered with the site occupancies assigned to 0.476 and 0.524, respectively. Three methyl hydrogen atoms of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were varied between two mirror-symmetric positions with the equal site occupancy. The crystallographic data for the four complexes were listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>, and the selected bond lengths and angles were given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>

elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and structure determinations
Diffraction intensities for 1–4 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker APEX–II QUAZAR diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073Å by using the φ–ω scan technique at 173 (for 1 and 2), 296 (for 3), and 150K (for 4), respectively. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semiempirical multi-scan absorption corrections were applied by sadabs
, and the program saint was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the shelxs-97 and shelxl-97 programs . Non-H atoms were located by difference Fourier maps and subjected to anisotropic refinement. Organic hydrogen atom was added according to theoretical models. Two and a half free water molecules in 3 were disordered, and the diffused electron densities resulting from these residual solvent molecules were removed from the data using the SQUEEZE routing of platon and refined further using the data generated . One exocyclic amino group (N10) of datrz− anion in 3 is positionally disordered with the site occupancies assigned to 0.476 and 0.524, respectively. Three methyl hydrogen atoms of CH3-ip2− ligand in 3 were varied between two mirror-symmetric positions with the equal site occupancy. The crystallographic data for the four complexes were listed in 
, and the selected bond lengths and angles were given in 



, respectively.

<ce:section-title id="st060">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st065">Syntheses and IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> bearing different 5-substituted isophthalate coligands were solvo/hydrothermally synthesized by significant varying the reaction temperatures of the reactant mixture. Other experimental conditions, such as the cobalt source, solvent medium, pH and reaction time, can also influence the formation of the crystalline products of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. In addition, the preparations of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with the same mixed ligands and different structures depended also on the molar ratio of Hdatrz and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (1:1 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 2: 1 for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). In the IR spectra, a broad absorption centered at <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 3400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is resulting from the stretching vibration of O–H, confirming the presence of water molecule. One (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) or two weak bands at 3349–3070<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> should be ascribed to the stretching vibrations of N–H, suggesting the occurrence of exocyclic amino group of triazolate ligand. Characteristic weak absorptions for aromatic C–H vibration is observed at approximately 3100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. As compared with the free organic acids, the disappearance of a strong band at 1698, 1702 and 1719<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is an indicative of the full deprotonation of the three substituted isophthalate coligands. Correspondingly, the multiple bands for the asymmetric (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>) and symmetric (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group are observed between 1670 and 1348<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and their different separations suggest the variable coordination modes of the carboxylate group .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Syntheses and IR spectra
Complexes 1–4 bearing different 5-substituted isophthalate coligands were solvo/hydrothermally synthesized by significant varying the reaction temperatures of the reactant mixture. Other experimental conditions, such as the cobalt source, solvent medium, pH and reaction time, can also influence the formation of the crystalline products of 1–4. In addition, the preparations of 2 and 3 with the same mixed ligands and different structures depended also on the molar ratio of Hdatrz and CH3-H2ip (1:1 for 2 and 2: 1 for 3). In the IR spectra, a broad absorption centered at ca. 3400cm−1 in 1, 3 and 4 is resulting from the stretching vibration of O–H, confirming the presence of water molecule. One (for 1) or two weak bands at 3349–3070cm−1 in 1–4 should be ascribed to the stretching vibrations of N–H, suggesting the occurrence of exocyclic amino group of triazolate ligand. Characteristic weak absorptions for aromatic C–H vibration is observed at approximately 3100cm−1. As compared with the free organic acids, the disappearance of a strong band at 1698, 1702 and 1719cm−1 in 1–4 is an indicative of the full deprotonation of the three substituted isophthalate coligands. Correspondingly, the multiple bands for the asymmetric (ν
as) and symmetric (ν
s) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group are observed between 1670 and 1348cm−1, and their different separations suggest the variable coordination modes of the carboxylate group .

<ce:section-title id="st070">Crystal structure of {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hdatrz)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a wave-like two-dimensional (2D) layer with dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunits extended by three-branched NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains two Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> octahedra, one neutral Hdatrz molecule, two doubly deprotonated NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions in the same binding mode and half a free water molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, both unique Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions are in the distorted N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> donor sets defined by one triazolyl group of Hdatrz ligand, one amino group from a NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, one bidentate chelating and two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups from three separate NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions. The Co–O and Co–N separations are between 2.0404(19) and 2.2704(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (), which are comparable with those cobalt(II)-based complexes with triazolyl and carboxylate ligands .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Co2(Hdatrz)(NH2-ip)2]·0.5H2O}n (1)
Complex 1 presents a wave-like two-dimensional (2D) layer with dimeric {Co2(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}4+ subunits extended by three-branched NH2-ip2− ligands. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two CoII octahedra, one neutral Hdatrz molecule, two doubly deprotonated NH2-ip2− anions in the same binding mode and half a free water molecule. As shown in 
a, both unique CoII ions are in the distorted N2O4 donor sets defined by one triazolyl group of Hdatrz ligand, one amino group from a NH2-ip2− anion, one bidentate chelating and two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups from three separate NH2-ip2− anions. The Co–O and Co–N separations are between 2.0404(19) and 2.2704(17)Å (), which are comparable with those cobalt(II)-based complexes with triazolyl and carboxylate ligands .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The unique Co1 and Co2 octahedra are hold together by one neutral μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand, generating a dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunit with the intermetallic separation of 3.6810(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Acting as a three-connected connector, the doubly deprotonated NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> coligand present its amino and two deprotonated carboxylate moieties to extend the dimeric subunits into a corrugated 2D layer with the inter-dimeric Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>⋯Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> separations of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 11.7, 9.0 and 10.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (b), which are much longer than that bridged by μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand. The isolated 2D sheets of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> interact with each other <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> N–H⋯O hydrogen-bonding interactions between the triazolyl moiety of Hdatrz ligand and the carboxylate group of the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the interlayer distance of 8.85069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The unique Co1 and Co2 octahedra are hold together by one neutral μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand, generating a dimeric {Co2(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}4+ subunit with the intermetallic separation of 3.6810(3)Å. Acting as a three-connected connector, the doubly deprotonated NH2-ip2− coligand present its amino and two deprotonated carboxylate moieties to extend the dimeric subunits into a corrugated 2D layer with the inter-dimeric CoII⋯CoII separations of ca. 11.7, 9.0 and 10.3Å (b), which are much longer than that bridged by μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand. The isolated 2D sheets of 1 interact with each other via N–H⋯O hydrogen-bonding interactions between the triazolyl moiety of Hdatrz ligand and the carboxylate group of the NH2-ip2− anion, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture of 1 with the interlayer distance of 8.85069Å ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Crystal structure of [Co(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)(Hdatrz)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pna</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> space group (), exhibiting a robust 3D framework with helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chains interconnected by bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> linkers. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains one Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, one neutral μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz molecule, one doubly deprotonated CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion and one terminally coordinated methanol molecule. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a, the sole Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry surrounded by two N and four O donors from two separate Hdatrz molecules, one terminal methanol molecule, two bidentate chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups from two different CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions. The bond lengths of Co–O and Co–N are comparable to those of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (). Adjacent Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> octahedra in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are periodically extended by μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz ligands, generating a helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chain running along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis with the intermetallic separation of 6.3070(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (b). The intermetallic separation by μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz is moderate longer by 2.63<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å than that by μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, being expected to transfer weak magnetic interaction. Furthermore, adjacent chains of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are crosslinked through bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, generating a robust 3D framework with the interchain Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>⋯Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> separation of 8.2813(2) Ǻ (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Co(CH3OH)(Hdatrz)(CH3-ip)]n (2)
Complex 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pna21 space group (), exhibiting a robust 3D framework with helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chains interconnected by bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH3-ip2− linkers. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one CoII ion, one neutral μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz molecule, one doubly deprotonated CH3-ip2− anion and one terminally coordinated methanol molecule. As illustrated in 
a, the sole CoII ion in 2 also adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry surrounded by two N and four O donors from two separate Hdatrz molecules, one terminal methanol molecule, two bidentate chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups from two different CH3-ip2− anions. The bond lengths of Co–O and Co–N are comparable to those of 1 (). Adjacent CoII octahedra in 2 are periodically extended by μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz ligands, generating a helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chain running along the crystallographic a-axis with the intermetallic separation of 6.3070(1)Å (b). The intermetallic separation by μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz is moderate longer by 2.63Å than that by μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz in 1, being expected to transfer weak magnetic interaction. Furthermore, adjacent chains of 2 are crosslinked through bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH3-ip2− ligands, generating a robust 3D framework with the interchain CoII⋯CoII separation of 8.2813(2) Ǻ (c).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st080">Crystal structure of {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Constructed from same mixed ligands and the spin carrier as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> features a microporous pillared-layer framework with corner-sharing triangular {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1,N2,N4-datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> layers and anionic CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> pillars. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains two Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> tetrahedra, a pair of monodeprotonated datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions in the same binding manner, a couple of half-a-CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions with mirror-symmetry, as well as two and a half disordered lattice water molecules. Different from the octahedral coordination geometries in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, both unique Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are in the pseudotetrahedral coordination environments completed by one monodentate carboxylate O atom from one CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>-</ce:italic>ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> coligand and three triazolyl N donors coming from three separate datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Co–O and Co–N bond lengths are slightly shorter than those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (), and comparable with the previously reported tetrahedral Co(II)-containing complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Co2(datrz)2(CH3-ip)]·2.5H2O}n (3)
Constructed from same mixed ligands and the spin carrier as 2, 3 features a microporous pillared-layer framework with corner-sharing triangular {Co2(μ3-N1,N2,N4-datrz)2}2+ layers and anionic CH3-ip2− pillars. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains two CoII tetrahedra, a pair of monodeprotonated datrz− anions in the same binding manner, a couple of half-a-CH3-ip2− anions with mirror-symmetry, as well as two and a half disordered lattice water molecules. Different from the octahedral coordination geometries in 1 and 2, both unique CoII ions in 3 are in the pseudotetrahedral coordination environments completed by one monodentate carboxylate O atom from one CH3
-ip2− coligand and three triazolyl N donors coming from three separate datrz− anions (
a). The Co–O and Co–N bond lengths are slightly shorter than those in 1 and 2 (), and comparable with the previously reported tetrahedral Co(II)-containing complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Different from the μ-N1,N2- and μ-N1,N4-bridging modes in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the deprotonated datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> adopts a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1,N2,N4-binding mode to aggregate pairs of symmetry-related Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions (Co1 and Co1A, as well as Co2 and Co2B) into a bimetallic {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> dimer through N1 and N2 sites and further extend the dimeric subunits through the N4 position (b). Notably, two unique {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> subunits are perpendicular to each other, generating a wavy 2D layer with (4, 8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology on the crystallographic <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane. The nearest Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>⋯Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> separations generated by two unique μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1,N2,N4-datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands are 3.72–6.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ǻ (b), implying a corner-sharing triangular magnetic lattice with lower symmetry. Each undulated layer of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is periodically pillared by the two crystallographically independent, mirror-symmetric CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> pillars in the same bis-monodentate binding mode, generating a 3D microporous pillared-layer framework of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with the interlayer intermetallic distance of 10.2565(22) and 10.2592(22)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (c). A calculation with PLATON reveals that the total potential solvent area is 1395.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, in which the volume of each unit cell is 4660.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Different from the μ-N1,N2- and μ-N1,N4-bridging modes in 1 and 2, the deprotonated datrz− anion in 3 adopts a μ3-N1,N2,N4-binding mode to aggregate pairs of symmetry-related CoII ions (Co1 and Co1A, as well as Co2 and Co2B) into a bimetallic {Co2(datrz)2}2+ dimer through N1 and N2 sites and further extend the dimeric subunits through the N4 position (b). Notably, two unique {Co2(datrz)2}2+ subunits are perpendicular to each other, generating a wavy 2D layer with (4, 82) topology on the crystallographic ac plane. The nearest CoII⋯CoII separations generated by two unique μ3-N1,N2,N4-datrz− ligands are 3.72–6.13Ǻ (b), implying a corner-sharing triangular magnetic lattice with lower symmetry. Each undulated layer of 3 is periodically pillared by the two crystallographically independent, mirror-symmetric CH3-ip2− pillars in the same bis-monodentate binding mode, generating a 3D microporous pillared-layer framework of 3 with the interlayer intermetallic distance of 10.2565(22) and 10.2592(22)Å, respectively (c). A calculation with PLATON reveals that the total potential solvent area is 1395.2Å3, in which the volume of each unit cell is 4660.9Å3.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">Crystal structure of {[Co(datrz)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in the chiral <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2 space group (), exhibiting a 2D (4, 4) sheet with tetrahedral Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ions extended by pairs of bi-monodentate NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and μ-N1,N4-datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> contains one crystallographically independent Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> site, one deprotonated datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, one doubly deprotonated NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, as well as one lattice water molecule. The unique Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> site in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is in a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> donor set completed by pairs of symmetry-related datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a), adopting a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (). The average Co–O and Co–N bond lengths of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are slightly shorter (∼0.028<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) than those in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> presents its two N donors to coordinate with the Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion in a bidentate μ-N1,N4-bridging mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Co(datrz)(NO2-ip)]·H2O}n (4)
Complex 4 crystallizes in the chiral P41212 space group (), exhibiting a 2D (4, 4) sheet with tetrahedral CoIII ions extended by pairs of bi-monodentate NO2-ip2− and μ-N1,N4-datrz− anions. The asymmetric unit of 4 contains one crystallographically independent CoIII site, one deprotonated datrz− anion, one doubly deprotonated NO2-ip2− anion, as well as one lattice water molecule. The unique CoIII site in 4 is in a N2O2 donor set completed by pairs of symmetry-related datrz− and NO2-ip2− ligands (
a), adopting a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (). The average Co–O and Co–N bond lengths of 4 are slightly shorter (∼0.028Å) than those in 3. The datrz− ligand in 4 presents its two N donors to coordinate with the CoIII ion in a bidentate μ-N1,N4-bridging mode.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Adjacent Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ions in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are periodically connected by pairs of bis-monodentate NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and μ-N1,N4-datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> heterobridges, generating a grid-based (4, 4) layer with the closet Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>⋯Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> distance of being 7.8056(5) and 6.0743(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (b). Furthermore, the individual layers of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are stacked together into a 3D supramolecular network through O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between the lattice water and the nitro/carboxylate group of NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Adjacent CoIII ions in 4 are periodically connected by pairs of bis-monodentate NO2-ip2− and μ-N1,N4-datrz− heterobridges, generating a grid-based (4, 4) layer with the closet CoIII⋯CoIII distance of being 7.8056(5) and 6.0743(4)Å, respectively (b). Furthermore, the individual layers of 4 are stacked together into a 3D supramolecular network through O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between the lattice water and the nitro/carboxylate group of NO2-ip2− ligand ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st090">PXRD and thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns of the four bulk products were in good agreement with each other (), indicating their phase purity and the structural consistency as the synthesized samples. TG experiments of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carried out in order to explore their thermal stability (). As a result, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed a slight weight-loss process between 60 and 145<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the release of the lattice water molecule, and was followed by a rapid weight-loss stage between 376 and 550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the decomposition of the layered structure. The remaining residue of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was calculated to be CoO above 550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (expt. 25.5%, calc. 25.7%). Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited one continuous weight-loss process above 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the continuous removal of methanol and the combustion of the mixed ligands. The final product of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> above 445<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was calculated to be CoO (expt. 21.6%, calc. 20.4%). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showed a two-step weight-loss stage between 60 and 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the slow release of disordered lattice molecules (expt. 8.3%, calc. 8.4%). Once the temperature was higher than 427<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the polymeric backbone collapse of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> occurred, which was completely finished at the highest temperature measured. Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was thermally stable up to 241<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and was accompanied by a continuous weight-loss process between 241<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 315<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the remove of lattice water molecule (expt. 6.1%, calc. 4.7%). The second obvious weight-loss stage between 370 and 533<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was resulting from the decomposition of the mixed ligands, leaving Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> as final product of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (expt. 22.2%, calc. 21.6%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and thermal stability of 1–4

Experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns of the four bulk products were in good agreement with each other (), indicating their phase purity and the structural consistency as the synthesized samples. TG experiments of 1–4 were carried out in order to explore their thermal stability (). As a result, complex 1 displayed a slight weight-loss process between 60 and 145°C for the release of the lattice water molecule, and was followed by a rapid weight-loss stage between 376 and 550°C for the decomposition of the layered structure. The remaining residue of 1 was calculated to be CoO above 550°C (expt. 25.5%, calc. 25.7%). Complex 2 exhibited one continuous weight-loss process above 100°C, corresponding to the continuous removal of methanol and the combustion of the mixed ligands. The final product of 2 above 445°C was calculated to be CoO (expt. 21.6%, calc. 20.4%). Complex 3 showed a two-step weight-loss stage between 60 and 180°C for the slow release of disordered lattice molecules (expt. 8.3%, calc. 8.4%). Once the temperature was higher than 427°C, the polymeric backbone collapse of 3 occurred, which was completely finished at the highest temperature measured. Complex 4 was thermally stable up to 241°C, and was accompanied by a continuous weight-loss process between 241°C and 315°C for the remove of lattice water molecule (expt. 6.1%, calc. 4.7%). The second obvious weight-loss stage between 370 and 533°C was resulting from the decomposition of the mixed ligands, leaving Co2O3 as final product of 4 (expt. 22.2%, calc. 21.6%).

</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−6.73<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (). Because the spin–orbit coupling can contribute the negative value of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>, the small <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may imply weak magnetic interaction between Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. From the viewpoints of the magnetostructural relationship, the magnetic couplings of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> substantially occurred within the binuclear subunit due to the short intermetallic distance (3.6810(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Thus, the experimental susceptibility of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was analyzed with an exchange-coupled high-spin cobalt(II) dimer consisting of the spin–orbit coupling (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>), low-symmetry (noncubic) crystal-field term (zero field splitting parameter <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>), magnetic exchange between Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>) and Zeeman interaction using a MagSaki software  in the whole temperature range, leading to <ce:italic>D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

The small and negative value of <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> confirms the weak antiferromagnetic coupling in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> mediated by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Magnetic properties
Variable temperature (2–300K) magnetic susceptibilities of the crystalline samples of 1–3 were measured under an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1kOe. As presented in 
a, the χ
M
T value for each binuclear subunit of 1 is 6.20cm3
Kmol−1 at 300K, which is much higher than the spin-only value (3.75cm3
Kmol−1) expected for two high-spin CoII octahedra (S
=3/2, g
=2) due to the significant orbital contribution. The χ
M
T product decreases continuously with the lowering temperature and reaches a value of 1.47cm3
Kmol−1 at 2.0K. Furthermore, the plot of χ
M
−1 versus T above 26.0K obeys the Curie-Weiss law with C
=6.33cm3
Kmol−1 and θ
=−6.73K (). Because the spin–orbit coupling can contribute the negative value of θ, the small θ of 1 may imply weak magnetic interaction between CoII ions. From the viewpoints of the magnetostructural relationship, the magnetic couplings of 1 substantially occurred within the binuclear subunit due to the short intermetallic distance (3.6810(3)Å) by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz− and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Thus, the experimental susceptibility of 1 was analyzed with an exchange-coupled high-spin cobalt(II) dimer consisting of the spin–orbit coupling (λ), low-symmetry (noncubic) crystal-field term (zero field splitting parameter D), magnetic exchange between CoII ions (J) and Zeeman interaction using a MagSaki software  in the whole temperature range, leading to D
=132cm−1, λ
=−82cm−1, J
=−1.13cm−1, Δ (axial-splitting parameter)=543, κ (orbital reduction factor)=0.92, gz

=2.3, gx

=5.0. The parameters of D, λ, Δ, κ, gz
 and gx
 are comparable with the reported binuclear CoII complexes with the triple bridges . The small and negative value of J confirms the weak antiferromagnetic coupling in 1 mediated by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Additionally, a peak at 2.5K is observed in the χ
M versus T curve under 1kOe, indicating an antiferromagnetic ordering of 1 at low field (a inset). Once the external magnetic field is higher than 10kOe, the peak in the χ
M versus T curve disappears (), suggesting a metamagnetic transition of 1 at high fields.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The magnetization of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> measured at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K gives a sigmoid-shaped increase with the increased external magnetic field (b). The magnetization at the highest field (5.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>Nβ</ce:italic>) is the same as that for two octahedral Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions with <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 and <ce:italic>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.1–5.0, indicating a weak ferromagnetic state of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at high field. This behavior indicates a metamagnetic transition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with critical field of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic> 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe determined by the d<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>/d<ce:italic>H</ce:italic> curve (b inset). The metamagnetism of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be rationalized to be a result of the competition between magnetic coupling within the binuclear subunit and the external field. At the low fields, the anti-parallel alignment of the magnetic moments from the binuclear subunits can lead to an antiferromagnetic ordering. Once the field exceeds 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe, weak intra-subunit antiferromagnetic interaction can be overcome by the enhanced field to lead to a weak ferromagnetic state of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

The magnetization of 1 measured at 2.0K gives a sigmoid-shaped increase with the increased external magnetic field (b). The magnetization at the highest field (5.23

=1/2 and g
=4.1–5.0, indicating a weak ferromagnetic state of 1 at high field. This behavior indicates a metamagnetic transition of 1 with critical field of ca 13kOe determined by the dM/dH curve (b inset). The metamagnetism of 1 can be rationalized to be a result of the competition between magnetic coupling within the binuclear subunit and the external field. At the low fields, the anti-parallel alignment of the magnetic moments from the binuclear subunits can lead to an antiferromagnetic ordering. Once the field exceeds 13kOe, weak intra-subunit antiferromagnetic interaction can be overcome by the enhanced field to lead to a weak ferromagnetic state of 1.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st100">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Four polymeric 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole-based metal complexes were obtained by varying the 5-substituted isophthalate coligands. Resulting from the variations of the metal coordination polyhedra and binding modes of the mixed ligands, these complexes exhibit dimeric subunit, helical chain and corner-sharing triangular layered motifs, which are further extended into 2D layers and 3D frameworks by ditopic and three-branched substituted isophthalate coligands. Metamagnetic and weak antiferromagnetic interactions are significantly mediated by the cyclic triazolate and substituent isophthalate connectors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
Four polymeric 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole-based metal complexes were obtained by varying the 5-substituted isophthalate coligands. Resulting from the variations of the metal coordination polyhedra and binding modes of the mixed ligands, these complexes exhibit dimeric subunit, helical chain and corner-sharing triangular layered motifs, which are further extended into 2D layers and 3D frameworks by ditopic and three-branched substituted isophthalate coligands. Metamagnetic and weak antiferromagnetic interactions are significantly mediated by the cyclic triazolate and substituent isophthalate connectors.
